criteria.name: Retrieval Relevance
criteria.description: How well the retrieval strategy returns information relevant to the query, including ranking optimization and validation.

levels.1: Retrieved information is irrelevant to the query. No alignment between query intent and returned results.
levels.2: Partially relevant results. Some retrieved items match the query, but significant noise or off-topic content is present.
levels.3: Relevant results for common query types. The retrieval strategy consistently returns on-topic information for standard queries.
levels.4: High relevance with ranking optimization. Results are not only relevant but properly ranked by importance, with top results being the most useful.
levels.5: Precision-tuned retrieval with validation. Retrieval is optimized for both precision and recall, with automated validation checks confirming result quality.

criteria.name: Coverage Completeness
criteria.description: How thoroughly the retrieval strategy covers all information needed to answer the query, including multi-hop and fallback coverage.

levels.1: Major information gaps. Critical facts needed to answer the query are missing from retrieval results.
levels.2: Core facts covered. The most essential information is retrieved, but secondary or supporting details are missing.
levels.3: Comprehensive coverage for the query scope. All information directly relevant to the query is retrieved, including supporting context.
levels.4: Multi-hop coverage with bridging entities. The strategy successfully traverses multiple relationships, retrieving intermediate entities needed for reasoning chains.
levels.5: Exhaustive coverage with fallback strategies. All relevant information is retrieved, with fallback mechanisms (iterative deepening, query relaxation) ensuring completeness even for edge cases.

criteria.name: Provenance Quality
criteria.description: How well the system tracks and presents the origin, confidence, and evidence chain for each piece of retrieved information.

levels.1: No source tracking. Retrieved information has no metadata about its origin or reliability.
levels.2: Basic source IDs attached. Each retrieved fact includes a source document identifier, but no additional metadata.
levels.3: Full provenance with timestamps and confidence. Each fact carries source ID, extraction timestamp, confidence score, and extraction method.
levels.4: Evidence chains with multi-source aggregation. Facts include full provenance plus evidence chains showing derivation, with confidence adjusted for multiple supporting sources.
levels.5: Auditable provenance with conflict resolution. Complete evidence trails, multi-source aggregation, conflict detection between disagreeing sources, and resolution strategies documented.

criteria.name: Query Handling
criteria.description: The range and sophistication of query types the retrieval strategy can handle, from simple lookups to adaptive multi-pattern processing.

levels.1: Only simple lookups. The strategy handles single-entity, single-hop factoid queries and nothing more.
levels.2: Basic pattern matching. Handles simple lookups plus basic keyword and embedding similarity searches.
levels.3: Multi-hop and decomposed queries. The strategy supports query decomposition for complex questions and can traverse multiple relationships.
levels.4: Hybrid symbolic-neural query processing. Combines structured graph queries (Cypher/SPARQL) with neural embedding search for flexible, precise retrieval.
levels.5: Adaptive strategy selection per query type. The system automatically classifies incoming queries and selects the optimal retrieval pattern (global-first, local-first, hybrid, temporal, constraint-guided) for each.

criteria.name: Hallucination Prevention
criteria.description: The effectiveness of safeguards preventing the system from returning or generating information not grounded in the knowledge graph.

levels.1: No safeguards. The system has no mechanisms to detect or prevent hallucinated content in retrieval or generation.
levels.2: Basic filtering. Simple checks such as removing results below a minimum similarity threshold.
levels.3: Constraint-guided filtering with type checking. Results are validated against schema constraints, entity types, and relationship types to filter implausible retrievals.
levels.4: Multi-stage verification with KG grounding. Retrieved results are cross-checked against the knowledge graph structure, with LLM-generated claims verified against retrieved evidence.
levels.5: Stepwise verification with confidence thresholds. Every claim in the generated output is individually verified against source evidence, with confidence thresholds determining inclusion and phrasing certainty.
